stem: A 28-year-old male patient with a T6 spinal cord injury is admitted to the medical-surgical unit. At 14:00, the patient reports a severe headache and nasal congestion. The nurse assesses the patient and obtains the following data: Blood pressure 210/110 mmHg, heart rate 52 bpm, flushed face, and diaphoresis above the level of injury. Based on these findings, which of the following interventions should the nurse implement *first*?

itemContext.sbar:
S: James Riley, a 28-year-old male with a T6 spinal cord injury, is experiencing symptoms indicative of autonomic dysreflexia, including a severe headache and nasal congestion. He reports feeling unwell.
B: Mr. Riley has a history of a T6 spinal cord injury sustained three years ago in a motor vehicle accident. He independently manages his bowel program and intermittent catheterization at home. He is familiar with the signs and symptoms of autonomic dysreflexia and typically manages episodes at home.
A: At 14:00, the patient's vital signs are significantly elevated: BP 210/110 mmHg, HR 52 bpm. He presents with a flushed face, diaphoresis above the T6 level, and nasal congestion. He is alert and oriented but reports a throbbing headache.
R: I recommend immediate interventions to address the dangerously elevated blood pressure and identify the underlying trigger for this episode of autonomic dysreflexia. I will continue to closely monitor his vital signs, neurological status, and implement interventions per protocol.

tabs.title: Labs
tabs.content: Na: 138 mEq/L, K: 4.1 mEq/L, Creatinine: 0.9 mg/dL, WBC: 7.5 x 10^3/uL, RBC: 4.8 x 10^6/uL, Urine analysis pending.

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content: Scheduled: Docusate 100mg PO daily, Polyethylene Glycol 17 g PO PRN constipation, Baclofen 20mg PO TID. PRN: Hydralazine 10mg IV PRN BP > 180/100 mmHg.

tabs.title: Vitals
tabs.content: 13:00: BP 140/88 mmHg, HR 78 bpm, RR 18, SpO2 98% on room air, Temp 98.6°F. 14:00: BP 210/110 mmHg, HR 52 bpm, RR 20, SpO2 99% on room air.

topicTags: Neurological: Spinal Cord Injury & Autonomic Dysreflexia

rationale.correct:
Elevate the head of the bed to 90 degrees: This is the initial intervention to reduce blood pressure by promoting venous pooling and decreasing cardiac workload.
Assess for bladder distension: Bladder distention is the most common cause of autonomic dysreflexia. Catheterize the patient if indicated to relieve pressure.
Loosen any tight clothing: Removing restrictive clothing, such as abdominal binders or tight socks, can improve circulation and reduce blood pressure.
Check the patient's bowel for impaction: Bowel impaction is another common trigger for autonomic dysreflexia. Perform a digital rectal examination to assess for and remove any impaction.
Administer PRN Hydralazine 10mg IV as ordered: Hydralazine is an antihypertensive medication used to treat severe hypertension associated with autonomic dysreflexia. Given the elevated BP, this is warranted after initial interventions to address the underlying cause.
rationale.incorrect:
Notify the physician: While notifying the physician is important to update them on the patient's status and response to treatment, the nurse should first implement interventions to address the immediate threat to the patient's safety. Delaying critical interventions while waiting to notify the physician could lead to serious complications.
Administer oxygen at 2L/min via nasal cannula: The patient's oxygen saturation is 99% on room air, indicating adequate oxygenation. Administering supplemental oxygen is not indicated at this time and would not address the underlying cause of the autonomic dysreflexia.
clinicalPearls: Autonomic dysreflexia is a medical emergency that requires prompt recognition and intervention.
Elevated blood pressure in patients with spinal cord injuries at or above T6 should always raise suspicion for autonomic dysreflexia.
Always prioritize identifying and addressing common triggers like bladder distension or bowel impaction before administering medications.

questionTrap.trap: The question traps the test-taker into thinking that notifying the physician immediately is the correct initial action. While important for ongoing communication, it delays immediate, life-saving interventions.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Prioritize interventions based on the ABCs (Airway, Breathing, Circulation) and address the most immediate threat to the patient's well-being first. In this case, the extremely high blood pressure necessitates immediate action to reduce the risk of stroke or other complications before notifying the physician.

mnemonic.title: SIT UP
mnemonic.expansion:
S – Sit the patient UP (elevate head of bed)
I – Investigate cause (bladder, bowel, skin)
T – Treat the BP (antihypertensives)
U – Unfasten tight clothing or constricting devices
P – Provider notification
